awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Variation in Socio-Environmental System Response to Glacial Recession
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Rapid glacier recession presents a unique opportunity to explore how environmental forces shape human actions while being shaped by them in return. While research on increasing environmental variability justifiably continues to focus on understanding the physical characteristics of glacier retreat, not enough research addresses the impacts of glacial retreat on evolving, socially created landscapes built around glaciers. As a result, resiliency and climate adaptation policies may fail because they ignore the complex social relationships and historical particularities that shaped societies in glacial environments to begin with and pay insufficient attention to how human relationships with both other humans and their environment evolve as glaciers melt. This doctoral dissertation research project asks how human and human-environmental relations influence the formation of transforming landscapes and livelihoods. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project results will be disseminated to organizational stakeholders that can optimize climate adaptation policies. This project also broadens the participation of groups underrepresented in science.

This comparative research project, conducted in two melting glacial valleys, examines how unevenly situated stakeholders adapt to, circumvent or exploit glacial melt. Pilot research revealed a glacial valley where stakeholders, including indigenous and other local communities, scientists, miners and policymakers, were more concerned with claiming rights to newly accessible land and resources than with impending water scarcity. This points to a potential gap between climate adaptation policies, focused on vulnerability, and actual lived experiences of environmental change. Via in-depth and semi-structured interviews and mobile observational elicitation techniques, this project explores variation in the ways which climate change impacts stakeholders’ present and immediate future, providing insights into the potential range of human responses to glacial melt at a global level. Results from the research improve scientific understanding of the transformation of human-environmental systems in response to climate change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rapid glacial melt worldwide has led to the transformation of the socio-natural landscapes glaciers are a part. While scholars have amply documented the issues that arise from accelerated deglaciation, much less is known about how people continue living under changing circumstances. This comparative ethnographic project, conducted over 25 months, documents the lived experiences of various actors – including indigenous peoples, pastoralists, scientists, miners, tourism industry employees, mountaineers, and state employees – of melting glaciers in two neighboring, South American countries: Bolivia and Argentina. Both field sites (Milluni Valley, La Paz and Malargüe, Mendoza) – located in Bolivia’s Tropical and Argentina’s Subtropical Andes, respectively – share important similarities and differences. As arid, high elevation terrains with low-brush vegetation, these regions have been characterized since the 19th century by each state and their respective elites as wasted or uninhabited deserts. Field research showed that areas on or near melting glaciers have become enmeshed in historical and new disputes over territorial sovereignty and resources. While mainstream climate change discourses portray glacial melt as catastrophic, this dissertation found that melting glaciers can also open new opportunities to redraw the symbolic and material conditions of territorial disputes.

            This dissertation, grounded in over 75 in-depth and semi-structured interviews in each field site, as well as participant observation and walk-alongs, documented how various, unevenly situated actors contest and co-produce rapidly transforming environments. These processes play out symbolically through the production of meaning and knowledge, and materially, through daily practices, uses, and development of infrastructure. While glacial melt is certainly concerning to those on the ground, fieldwork showed that it is more meaningful to Indigenous communities when it impacts (whether positively or negatively) their ability to claim and/or maintain rights to land and belonging to each state and site. In landscapes portrayed as desertic and uninhabited, what is ultimately in dispute is the ancestral habitation of these areas by certain Indigenous communities. As discourses of climate change-induced ruin interact with extractive practices and colonial discourses on site that legitimize the dispossession of Indigenous peoples’ land, what is at stake when proving ancestral habitation in areas near melting glaciers is the ability to claim and belong to each site’s official history. Ultimately, this dissertation argues that global climate change discourses carry with them colonial value systems that erase indigenous peoples’ alternative stories of glacial melt and, in the process, impact their struggles to regain territorial sovereignty. In this context, this dissertation suggests the need to revise catastrophic global climate change discourses, generally meant to elicit ethical responses from the Global North. Changes in the landscape produced by melting glaciers interact with historical processes, the global and local political economy, and old and new, differently situated, actors’ interests, practices, and shifting power relations. A revised climate change narrative must consider the articulated set of capital and power relations, across scales, which interact with a transforming landscape and shape people’s possibilities of continuing to live near melting glaciers.

This project facilitated the training of two undergraduate Aymara indigenous students from the Public University of El Alto (UPEA), an Aymara indigenous sociologist, two Bolivian history students (UMSA) and an Argentine social science student from UNCuyo (all from public universities). Several interdisciplinary collaborations emerged from this project. These include: a) the “Life Without Ice” project with glaciologists, ecologists, biologists, and geographers from Bolivia and the French Institute for Research on Development (IRD). A book resulting from this collaboration will be published in 2025 and shared locally and in international conferences like the COP 2025. b) a project to historicize Mt. Chacaltaya (whose glacier melted in 2010) with a Bolivian physicist and two history students, c) co-written articles with colleagues from IANIGLA-CONICET in Argentina on the Glacier Law and Inventory, and d) an ongoing collaboration with a Mapuche community (currently facing territorial dispossession) in Mendoza to historicize the high mountain, portrayed as uninhabited, under a project called “Ancestral Trails”. Throughout fieldwork, preliminary results have been shared in community meetings, in guest lectures (in South America and the U.S), and local and international conferences. Once data is transcribed, sorted, and analyzed, material pertaining to each Indigenous community will be returned in the form of a booklet to add to their archive of historical material. This project has also facilitated several conversations with the current Municipal Director of the Department of the Environment in Malargüe, Mendoza (field site in Argentina) regarding climate change adaptation policy. Based on these conversations, and in collaboration with the Coordinator of the Argentina Glacier Inventory at IANIGLA-CONICET, the Director and I sent a proposal to the FAO-UN to fund a climate action plan with youth. Upon returning to the U.S., this project will be disseminated locally and potentially contribute to research in high mountain environments throughout California, particularly in sites facing issues regarding water scarcity, desertification, and territorial and resource disputes.
